lg.l: Ætatis suæ fifty two
A \add·Rich·(grave)·Divine·del·rev'rend D\del·ea·add·──\n\ \del·resolv'd·add·began\ to woo
A handsom young imperious Girl
\del·Philippa·daughter·add·Nearly related\ to an Earl.
\del·The·add·Her\ Parents and her Friends consent,
The Couple to the Temple went:,
They \del·fist·add·first\ invite the Cyprian Queen,
'Twas answerd, she would not be seen.,
\del·And·then·the·Graces·add and del·But Cupid in disdain could scarce
Forbear to bid them kiss his A──\
\add·And·then·the·\del·Graces·and\·Graces\·and·the·Muses·clarified·in·margin·The·Graces·next,·and·all·the·Muses\
W\ere·over·here\ bid in form, but sent Excuses:
Iuno attended·\del·attended\ at the Porch
With farthing Candle for a Torch,
While Mistress Iris held her Train,
The faded Bow \del·bedropt·with·add·distilling\ Rain.
\add·interlinearly·Then Hebe came and took her Place
But showd no more than half her Face\
Whate'er these dire fore-bodings meant,
In \del·Ioy·add·Mirth\ the \del·Marriage·add·wedding-\ day was spent.
The \del·Marriage·add·Wedding\-day, you take me right,
I promise nothing for the Night:
The Bridegroom dresst, to make a Figure,
\del··Arsss\·Assumes an artificiall Vigor;
A flourisht Night-cap on, to grace
His ruddy, wrinckled, \smirking·add·alternative·above·smiling\ Face,
Like the faint red upon a Pippin
Half wither'd \add·by·del·with\ a Winters keeping.
And, thus set out this happy Pair,
The Swain is rich, the Nymph is fair;
But, what I gladly would forget,
The Swain is old, the Nymph Coquette.
Both from the Goal together start;
Scarce run a Step before they part;
No common Ligament that binds
The various Textures of their Minds,
Their Thoughts, and Actions,, Hopes,, and Fears,
Less corresponding than their Years.
\The Dean·add·alternative·above·Her·Spouse\ desires his Coffee soon,,
She rises to her Tea at noon.
\The Dean·alt·above·While·He\ goes out to cheapen Books,
She at the Glass consults her Looks
While Betty's \del·tatling·add·buzzing\ at her Ear.
Lord, what a Dress these Parsons wear,
So odd a Choice, how could she make,,
Wish't him a Coll'nell for her Sake.
Then on her fingers Ends she counts
Exact to what his Age amounts,
The Dean, she heard her Uncle say
Is \sixty·add·alternative·above·fifty\, if he be a Day;
His ruddy \Looks·alt·above·Cheeks\ are no Disguise;
You see the Crows feet round his Eyes.
At one she rambles to the shops
To cheapen Tea, and talk with Fops,
Or calls a Councel of her Maids
And Tradesmen, to compare Brocades.
Her weighty Morning Bus'ness o'er
Sits down to Dinner just at four;,
Minds nothing that is done or said,
Her ev'ning Work so fills her Head;
The D\del·ea\n, who us'd to dine at one,
Is maukish, and his Stomach gone;
In threed-bare Goun, would scarce a louse hold,
Looks like the Chaplain of the Hous hold,
Beholds her from the Chaplain's Place
In \silver Stuffs·add·alternative·above·French·brocades\ and Flanders Lace;
He wonders what employs her Brain,.
But never asks, or asks in vain;
His Mind is full of other Cares
And in the Sneaking Parsons Airs
Computes, that half a Parish Dues
Will hardly find his Wife in shoes.
Canst thou imagine, dull Divine,
'Twill gain her Love to make her fine?
Hath she no other wants beside.?
You \del·feed·?her·?Lust·add·raise Desire\ as well as Pride,
Enticing Coxcombs to adore,
And teach her to despise thee more
\del·If by a more than usuall Grace
She lends him in her Chariot Place\
\add·and·del·If·in·her·Coach·she'll·condescend··To·place·him·at·the·hinder·End·add·If in her Coach she·'ll condescend
To place him at the hinder End\
Her Hoop is hoist above his Nose,
\del·For fear h·add·H\is·add·odious\ Gown \del·sh·add·w\ould soil her Cloaths,
And drop\del·t·add·s\ him at the Church, to pray
While she drives on to see the Play.
He like an orderly Divine
Comes home \del·three·add·a\ quar\del·ters·add·ter\ after nine,
And meets her hasting to the Ball,
Her Chairmen push him from the Wall:
\del·The Dean·add·He·enters\ gets in, and walks up Stairs,
\del·And·add·Then·also·crossed·out\ calls the Family to Prayrs,
Then goes alone to take his Rest
In bed, where he can spare her best.
At five the Footmen make a Din,
Her Ladyship is just come in,
The Masquerade began at two,
She stole away with much ado,
And shall be chid this afternoon
for leaving company so soon;
She'll say, and she \del·can·add·may\ truly say 't
She can't \del·endure·add·abide\ to stay out late.
But now, though scarce a twelmonth marry'd,
Poor \alt above·His\ Lady \add·in·another·hand[Deane Swift?]·Jane·del·?Phill\ has \del·thrice·add·twelve·times\ miscarry'd,
The \del·Town\·Cause, alas, is quickly guesst,
The Town has whisper'd round the Iest:
Think on some Remedy in time
\del·The·Dean,·you see,·is·add·You find his Rev'rence\ past his Prime,
Already dwindled to a Lath;
No other way but try the Bath:
For Venus rising from the Ocean
Infus'd a strong prolifick Potion,
That mixt with Achelous Spring,
The horned Floud, as Poets sing;
Who with an English Beauty smitten
Ran under Ground from Greece to Brittain,
The genial Virtue with him brought
And gave the Nymph a plenteous Draught;
Then fled, and left his Horn behind
For Husbands past their Youth to find;
The Nymph who still with Passion burnd,
Was to a boiling Fountain turn'd,
Where Childless wives crowd ev'ry morn
To drink in Achilous' Horn.
\del·Or bath beneath the Cross their Limbs
Where fruitfull Matter chiefly swims;\
And here the Father often gains
That Title by anothers Pains.
Hither, though much against his \del·will,·add·in·another·hand[Deane·Swift?]·Grain\
The D\del·ea·add·──\n has carry'd Lady \del·Phill.·add·in·another·hand[Deane Swift]·Jane\
He for a while would not consent,
But vow'd his Money all was spent;
\Was ever such a add·alternative·above·His Money spent?!\ \del·foolish·add·clownish\ Reason?
And, must my Lady slip her Season?
The Doctor with a double Fee
Was brib.'d to make the D\del·ea·add·──\n agree.
Here, all Diversions of the Place
Are proper in my Lady's Case
With which she patiently complyes,
Meerly because her Friends advise;
\del·Where if the Dean by chance appears,
It shames his Cassock and his Years;·add·and·then·del·in·margin,·perh·not·in·JS's·hand·Where·if·the·Dean by·chance·appears··It·shames·his·Cassock·&·his·Years.\
His Money and her Time employs
In musick, Raffling-rooms, and Toys,
Or in the cross-bath seeks an\del·d\ Heir
Since others oft have found one there;
\add·in·margin·Where if the Dean by chance appears
It shames his Cassock and his Years\
He keeps his Distance in the Gallery
Till banisht by some Coxcombs Raillery;
For, \?add·It·del·?·t\would his Character Expose
To bath among the Belles and Beaux.
So have I seen within a Pen
Young Ducklings, fosterd by a Hen;
But when let out, they run and muddle
As Instinct leads them, in a Puddle;
The Sober Hen not born to Swim
\del·Mean·while·stands·add and del·Pining·and\·del·chuckling·at·the·Brim.\··add·with mournfull Note·del·walks·add·clocks round the Brim.\
The D\del·ea·add·──\n with all his best Endeavor
Gets not an\del·d\ Heir, but gets a Feaver;
A Victim to the last Essays
Of Vigor in declining Days.
He dyes, and leaves his mourning Mate
\del·The·best·of·Heirs,·add·(What could he less,) his whole Estate,
The Widow goes through all her Forms:
New Lovers now will come in Swarms.
Oh, may I see her soon dispensing
Her Favors to some broken Ensign:
Him let her Marry for his Face,
And onely Coat of tarnish't Lace;
To turn her Naked out of Doors.,
And spend her Ioynture on his Whores:
But for a parting Present leave her
A rooted Pox to last for ever.
